definition: 91 BC attempted coup d'etat against Emperor Wu of Han 漢武帝|汉武帝, beginning with accusations of witchcraft
witch/wizard/shaman/also pr. [wu2]
surname Wu/also pr. [Wu2]
arch. legendary venomous insect/to poison/to bewitch/to drive to insanity/to harm by witchcraft/intestinal parasite
(possessive particle, literary equivalent of 的[de5])/him/her/it
old variant of 禍|祸[huo4]
disaster/misfortune/calamity
Emperor Xuan (91-48 BC) of the Former Han Dynasty, reigned 74-48 BC
Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty (141-87 BC)
Liu Shi, personal name of Han Emperor Yuandi 漢元帝|汉元帝[Han4 Yuan2 di4]
Xuanwu gate coup of June 626 in early Tang, in which Li Shimin 李世民 killed his brothers, seized the throne from his father as Emperor Taizong 唐太宗
Qin Ershi (229-207 BC), second Qin emperor
Emperor Wen of Han (202-157 BC), fourth Han emperor, personal name Liu Heng 劉恆|刘恒[Liu2 Heng2], reigned 180-157 BC
to commit suicide on the orders of a sovereign (old)
Emperor Hui of Jin (259-307), personal name 司馬衷|司马衷[Si1 ma3 Zhong1], 2nd emperor of Jin Dynasty 晉朝|晋朝[Jin4 chao2], reigned 290-307
Liu Heng (202-157 BC), the fourth Han emperor Han Wendi, reigned 180-157 BC
witchcraft
rebellion against Liang of the Southern Dynasties 南朝梁 in 548
Yuan Emperor, reign name of Han Dynasty emperor Liu Shi 劉奭|刘奭[Liu2 Shi4], (74-33 BC), reigned 48-33 BC
to corrupt politics
Emperor Ling of Han (156-189), reigned from 168 to 189
An-Shi Rebellion (755-763) of 安祿山|安禄山[An1 Lu4 shan1] and 史思明[Shi3 Si1 ming2], a catastrophic setback for Tang dynasty
